content_scrubbed:
Honestly, I wish that I could have chosen one of the smaller colleges I was admitted to. I feel like I would have liked it better. Not that I haven't liked Berkeley, but the campus can feel very impersonal at times. You have to work harder to create a smaller world. Also my department, Econ, has huge classes (like 200+ kids) even in the upper division electives which probably makes it worse than some other majors. However, I still think Berkeley was the_right choice given the prices involved. 

I don't think that UCLA (I was admitted to every UC) would have been very different though in this area.

To respond to some of the other criticism here: 

* The far leftists make a lot of noise but honestly most people just make fun of them in private. That being said, myself and most of my friends have realized that they actually do have a point in some areas, it[.] just that they over do it. Being exposed to different ideas (which I still disagree with) has made me grow and be more tolerant. None of my professors have been like this though.
* Academics hasn't been that hard for me, and I have a decent GPA. Generally, Econ is considered to be one of the harder departments but I think it[.] not as cut throat as other majors. I've felt that the few humanities classes I've taken have been a lot of reading although not that hard if you actually do it and participate in discussions, but very personally rewarding in expanding my worldview.
